description: Smallest prime p such that the quotient-cycle length in continued fraction expansion of sqrt(p) is n: smallest prime p(m) for which A054269(m)=n.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..2000
formula: a(n)=Min{p|A054269(sequence number of p)=n; p is prime}
example: The quotient-cycle length L=9=A054269(m) first appears for p(30)=113, so a(9)=113 namely, at first A054269(30)=9; a[A054269(30)]=p[30]=113=a(9). The quotient cycle with L=16 first emerges for sqrt[191] and it is: cfrac(sqrt(191),'periodic','quotients')= [[13],[1,4,1,1,3,2,2,13,2 2,3,1,1,4,1,26]]
author: _Labos Elemer_, Feb 23 2001
